dc:description: PINK1 was first reported in relation to autosomal-recessive Parkinson´s disease in 2004 (Valente et al. 2004, PMID: 15087508). Parkinson´s disease is a progressive degenerative disorder of the central nervous system characterized by loss of dopamine-producing neurons in the substantia nigra. Signs and symptoms include tremor, which is most pronounced during rest, muscle rigidity, slowing of voluntary movements (bradykinesia), and a tendency to fall back (postural instability). Many pathogenic variants in the biallelic state have been reported in PINK1 in about 200 patients by different authors/groups from different ethnicities (Kasten et al. 2018, PMID: 29644727, www.mdsgene.org). The mutational spectrum is broad, including nonsense, frameshift, splice site, missense changes, and also structural variants (e.g. exon deletions). Fifteen families from five publications are included in this curation, covering patients with biallelic missense or truncating variants. The additional evidence from the literature was not included in this curation because the maximum score for genetic evidence (12 pts.) has been reached. The disease follows a recessive mode of inheritance with seemingly full, age-dependent penetrance. Notably, there is an ongoing debate on the potential role of heterozygous variants as genetic risk factors for Parkinson´s disease (Klein et al. 2007, PMID: 17582365; Hu et al. 2022, PMID: 36305379). The gene-disease association is also supported by recurrent experimental evidence, including animal models and in-vitro functional assays. The mechanism of pathogenicity appears to be a loss-of-function (LOF) indicated by the many truncating variants and further supported by knock-out fly models (Park et al. 2006, PMID: 16672980; Wang et al. 2006, PMID: 16938835). There is a well-defined functional interaction with another autosomal-recessive Parkinson´s disease-linked gene, i.e. PRKN encoding Parkin. While Parkin functions as an E3-ubiquiting ligase for mitochondrial proteins, PINK1 serves as a sensor for disrupted mitochondria (Narendra et al. 2010, PMID: 20126261; Rakovic et al. 2010, PMID: 20508036). It has further repeatedly been shown that several of the PINK1 missense variants impair proper mitophagy (e.g. Kawajiri et al. 2010, PMID: 20153330; Ando et al. 2017, PMID: 28438176). In summary, biallelic, pathogenic variants in PINK1 are definitively causing autosomal-recessive Parkinson´s disease. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both the research and clinical diagnostic settings and has been upheld over time.

evidence.dc:description: p-Ser65-Ub signal increased in control cells over time but was undetectable in PINK1 p.I368N mutant cells upon treatment with CCCP
evidence.rdfs:label: p-Ser65-Ub signal

evidence.dc:description:
We found that the L347P patient
mutant of PINK1 is unstable (Figure 8C and Figure S6A), as was
reported previously [28], and that L347P failed to reconstitute
YFP-Parkin recruitment to depolarized mitochondria (Figure 8A
and 8B). Of the patient mutations that exhibited stable expression,
A168P and H271Q also failed to reconstitute YFP-Parkin
recruitment at 3 h,
evidence.rdfs:label: Recruitment of Parkin

evidence.detectionMethod:
The entire open reading frame of PINK1 was sequenced in all patients and in 80 NIH controls.The 8 exons with their exon-intron boundaries were amplified using polymerase chain reaction conditions.For proband 4685, the reverse transcription–polymerase chain reaction products
of PINK1 were amplified with primers placed in exons 1 and 8, they were cloned using a TA cloning kit (Invitrogen, Carlsbad, Calif ), and then 3 randomly selected clones were sequenced. Mutations were detected by direct inspection of the fluorescent chromatographs and analysis using SeqScape software version 1.0 (Applied Biosystems, Foster City, Calif ).The frequencies of the Glu240Lys and Leu489Pro mutations were evaluated in 100 controls using SNaPshot (Applied Biosystems). The frequency of the Leu347Pro in Filipino controls was evaluated using a restriction digest assay. Exon 5 was amplified as already described, it was digested overnight with 0.3 U of HpaII at 37°C, and the resulting restriction fragments were resolved on a 1.5% agarose gel.

evidence.rdfs:label: 1 (index)
evidence.detectionMethod:
Fine mapping of single-nucleotide polymorphisms and newly generated short tandem repeat markers in the three families defined a 2.8-megabase region of homozygosity within contig NT_004610, containing approximately 40 genes.
Candidate genes were prioritized on the basis of their putative function and expression in
the central nervous system, as assessed by bioinformatic analysis and by exon amplification from a human substantia nigra cDNA library. Sequence analysis of candidate genes in affected members from each family led to the identification of two homozygous mutations in ...
evidence.previousTestingDescription: We previously mapped PARK6, a locus linked to autosomal recessive, early-onset PD, to a 12.5-centimorgan (cM) region on chromosome 1p35-p36 by autozygosity mapping in a large consanguineous family from Sicily (3).

evidence.rdfs:label: FPD-125-2
evidence.detectionMethod:
For linkage analysis, the D1S478 microsatellite and two newly developed short tandem repeat markers (D1S3788 and D1S3787) were typed at the PARK6 locus. All the genotypes were generated by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) using fluorescently labelled primers and analysed
on an ABI 3730 automatic DNA analyser.In index cases of families putatively linked to PARK6 locus, the eight exons of PINK1 and their exon/intron boundaries were amplified by PCR, using standard methods.Bidirectional dideoxy chain terminator sequence products were loaded on an
ABI 3730 automated sequencer and analysed with DNA Sequencing Analysis (version 5.1) and Seqscape (version 2.1.1) softwares (Applied Biosystems).Available members of families with PINK1 mutations were analysed to verify segregation of the mutation.
evidence.previousTestingDescription:
A group of 143 patients were screened for parkin mutations, which were found on both alleles in 66 index cases and one parkin mutation (on a single allele) in 24 by direct sequen-
cing of the parkin gene and exon dosage methods

member.rdfs:label: A1
member.detectionMethod: Mutation analysis of PINK1 by direct sequencing of the polymerase chain reaction products. This was followed by exon sequencing on ABI377 and 310 automated DNA sequence analyzers (Applied Biosystems).
member.previousTestingDescription: We analyzed parkin mutations by direct sequencing of the coding regions including exon-intron boundaries using previously described primers.1 DJ-1 screening was also performed.We performed linkage analysis in 84 individuals.

member.rdfs:label: BO-22
member.detectionMethod:
For haplotype analysis, we typed short tandem repeat
(STR) markers from the PARK2 ( parkin), PARK6 (PINK1),
and PARK7 (DJ-1) regions, by polymerase chain reaction
(PCR) using fluorescently labeled primers and an ABI3100
automatic DNA analyzer, according to conditions reported
previously.For the mutation analysis, the eight exons of the PINK1
gene were amplified by PCR.
